text: And she called the name of the LORD that spake unto her, Thou God seest me: for she said, Have I also here looked after him that seeth me?
text_kjv: And she called the name of the LORD that spake unto her, Thou God seest me: for she said, Have I also here looked after him that seeth me?
text_niv: She gave this name to the Lord who spoke to her: “You are the God who sees me,” for she said, “I have now seen the One who sees me.”
text_esv: So she called the name of the LORD who spoke to her, “You are a God of seeing,”  for she said, “Truly here I have seen him who looks after me.”
text_nlt: Thereafter, Hagar used another name to refer to the LORD, who had spoken to her. She said, “You are the God who sees me.” She also said, “Have I truly seen the One who sees me?”
text_msg: She answered God by name, praying to the God who spoke to her,"You're the God who sees me!""Yes! He saw me; and then I saw him!"
text_nasb: Then she called the name of the LORD who spoke to her, 'You are a God who sees'; for she said, 'Have I even remained alive here after seeing Him?'
context: Genesis 16 occurs within the patriarchal narratives, a time when lineage and offspring were paramount, especially within the covenant God made with Abraham. The ancient Near Eastern culture deeply valued fertility. Barrenness was a source of shame and social stigma for women. Polygamy was a common practice, often employed as a means to ensure descendants. Sarai's offering of Hagar, her Egyptian maidservant, to Abram was culturally acceptable, even expected, given her inability to conceive. This action was intended to provide Abram with an heir through Hagar. Egyptian maids, such as Hagar, held a subservient position within the household and were considered property. The social hierarchy dictated that Sarai, as the mistress, held authority over Hagar. Hagar's subsequent pregnancy likely elevated her status, leading to the conflict and mistreatment described in the narrative. The name given to God, 'El Roi,' meaning 'the God who sees me,' holds profound significance in this historical context. It reflects Hagar's feelings of isolation, abandonment, and vulnerability as a foreigner, a slave, and a pregnant woman fleeing from abuse. The encounter with the angel of the Lord in the wilderness highlighted God's presence and concern even for the marginalized. This narrative sheds light on the complex social dynamics and the desperation surrounding the desire for children in that era.
meaning: Genesis 16:13 reveals a profound theological truth about God's character: He is El Roi, the God who sees. This seeing is not merely observation; it is an act of attentive care and compassionate engagement. Hagar's question, 'Have I also here looked after him that seeth me?' suggests a realization that she, in her distress, was not forgotten or overlooked by God. God’s vision penetrates all circumstances, even the desolate wilderness where Hagar found herself. This counters the notion of a distant or indifferent deity. Instead, El Roi is intimately involved in the lives of individuals, especially those who are suffering and marginalized. The name Hagar gives to God underscores the divine attribute of omniscience coupled with providential care. God not only knows our circumstances but also responds to them with mercy and grace. The theophany, the encounter with the angel of the Lord, is significant. In the Old Testament, the angel of the Lord is often understood as a pre-incarnate appearance of Christ, further emphasizing God's active intervention in human affairs. God's promise to Hagar about the future of her son, Ishmael, reinforces the idea that even amidst broken relationships and desperate situations, God has a plan and a purpose. This verse is a testament to God's unwavering presence and His commitment to see and care for those whom society often neglects.
application: Genesis 16:13 offers several powerful applications for modern living. First, it reminds us that God sees us in our pain, our struggles, and our loneliness. When we feel invisible or forgotten, we can remember Hagar's story and know that God is El Roi, the God who sees us. This encourages us to turn to Him in prayer and trust that He is aware of our circumstances and will provide comfort and guidance. Second, the verse challenges us to cultivate a heart of compassion for those who are marginalized and overlooked in our society. Just as God saw Hagar, a slave and a foreigner, we are called to see and care for those who are vulnerable and oppressed. This could involve volunteering our time, donating to charities, or simply extending kindness and empathy to those around us. Third, it encourages us to examine our own hearts and actions. Are we acting out of impatience or a lack of faith, like Sarai, trying to force God's hand? Or are we trusting in God's timing and His promises, even when things seem impossible? Fourth, this verse calls us to acknowledge God's sovereignty in all areas of our lives. Even when we make mistakes or find ourselves in difficult situations, we can trust that God is working all things together for our good. Finally, Hagar's experience teaches us the importance of recognizing God's presence in unexpected places. She encountered God in the wilderness, a place of desperation and isolation. We too can find God in the midst of our trials and challenges, if we open our hearts to Him.
prayer: Lord God, El Roi, the God who sees, thank you for seeing me, even when I feel invisible and alone. Thank you that your eyes are upon me and that you know every detail of my life. Forgive me for the times I have doubted your presence or felt that you have abandoned me. Help me to trust in your unwavering love and care, even in the midst of difficult circumstances. Give me a compassionate heart to see and care for those who are marginalized and overlooked in our society. Empower me to be your hands and feet, bringing hope and healing to a hurting world. Help me to rest in your sovereignty and to trust in your perfect timing. May I always seek your face and find comfort in your presence. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Sarai gave Hagar to Abram because she was barren and wanted to fulfill God's promise of offspring through Abram. This was a culturally accepted practice at the time, intending to provide Abram with an heir.
